items.title: What if errors were random, not systematic?
items.content:
You'd design: No debugging framework - just retry until it works.
Why this fails: Retrying without understanding just compounds errors. Same root cause produces same failure.
Hidden constraint revealed: OHIV works because agent failures ARE predictable.

items.title: The irreducible debugging flow
items.content:
git status && git diff HEAD~1 && npm test
Essential: Know state. Know changes. Know tests.
Everything else: Refinement for specific failure types.

items.title: 80% of failures, 3 causes
items.content: Research across 4,677+ GitHub issues: context exhaustion, missing verification, vague instructions. If you fix these three, you've addressed 80% of failure surface.

items.title: How context degrades (invisibly)
items.content:
100% to 90% (40-60K): Subtle drift, you won't notice
90% to 70% (60-80K): Repetition, compression
70% to 50% (80-100K): Instructions forgotten
50% to CLIFF (100K+): Hallucinations, amnesia

Critical: The gradient is invisible until the cliff.

items.title: OHIV = Scientific Method
items.content:
Observe → Gather evidence
Hypothesize → Form testable theory
Isolate → Controlled experiment
Verify → Confirm results

If you've debugged code before, you already know this method.

items.title: One constraint, five downstream implications
items.content:
ROOT: Errors compound exponentially if unaddressed
→ Must verify after EVERY iteration
→ Must stop at first detected issue
→ Must have checkpoints to return to
→ Must use external state for recovery
→ Must prefer restart over extended debugging

items.title: INV-001: Context degrades with tokens
items.content: Ralph, Gas Town, CC Mirror, and debugging ALL share this constraint. Every pattern must account for context as a depletable resource. Fresh context beats extended context.

items.title: Error amplification at scale
items.content:
Research finding: Independent agents amplify errors 17.2x. Centralized coordination contains this to 4.4x.

Implication: Hub-and-spoke architectures are essential for multi-agent debugging.

items.title: If you skip verification after each iteration
items.content:
IF: You continue with known problems
THEN: Error creates 3 new problems
THEN: 9 problems at iteration 3
THEN: 81 problems at iteration 5
FINALLY: Recovery cost exceeds original task

The fix: Stop at first failure. Never push through.

items.title: Debug depth vs. restart speed
items.content:
Deep debugging: Learn root cause, prevent future failures, but expensive
Quick restart: Fast recovery, but might hit same issue again
Heuristic: If >10 min debugging with no progress, restart is faster

items.title: How deep is your debugging?
items.content:
Beginner: "What tool do I use?" → Match symptom to tool table
Intermediate: "When to use each?" → Context vs. state vs. verification
Advanced: "Can I prevent this?" → Pre-session checklist
Staff: "What's the pattern?" → 5 failure categories
Expert: "How do tools compose?" → Claude HUD + Ralph + circuit breakers

items.title: Claude HUD + Ralph Loop
items.content:
Works: Real-time context monitoring prevents degradation.
Danger: HUD can't prevent all failures - still need circuit breakers.
Recommendation: Use HUD for monitoring, circuit breakers for automatic stopping.

items.title: How tool value changes over session length
items.content:
0-30 min: "Git tools seem unnecessary"
30-60 min: "Glad I can checkout previous state"
60+ min: "Git stash has saved me multiple times"
Multi-day: "External state IS the memory"

Don't judge tool value by short sessions.

items.title: What if you diagnosed by guessing?
items.content:
You'd do: Try random fixes until something works.
Why this fails: Most "fixes" compound the problem. Wrong hypothesis → wrong action → more errors.
Hidden constraint revealed: Systematic diagnosis is faster than guessing.

items.title: The 72-hour OAuth debugging
items.content: 9 engineers, 72 hours, 17 rewrites, 3.2M tokens. Code worse than when they started. Root cause: no decision tree, no systematic diagnosis, just "keep trying fixes."

items.title: When to stop debugging, start restarting
items.content:
0-5 min: Debug - likely quick fix
5-10 min: Debug with caution
10-15 min: Consider restart
15+ min: Restart almost certainly faster

THE INFLECTION: ~10 min
Detection: No progress in hypothesis-test cycles? Time to restart.

items.title: $47,000 recursive loop - 11 days unnoticed
items.content: No iteration limits. No budget caps. No human monitoring. No stuck detection. "The gap between demos and production is enormous."

items.title: Home directory deletion - GitHub #17164
items.content: rm -rf tests/ patches/ plan/ ~/ - trailing ~/ deleted entire home folder. --dangerously-skip-permissions with no blocklist.

items.title: Gas Town merge wall at 200k LOC
items.content: "It worked amazingly up to about 200k LOC, and now they've begun savagely overwriting each other's work." - Steve Yegge

items.title: Ryan Carson: 14 iterations for 6 stories
items.content: 2.3 iterations per story average. "The bottleneck isn't coding - it's the upfront spec quality: PRD clarity, atomic stories, and verifiable criteria."

items.title: UNSOLVED: Optimal circuit breaker thresholds
items.content: How many iterations before stopping? How many errors before alerting? Optimal varies by project. Marathon Ralph uses 3-5 per phase, but no universal formula exists.

items.title: The cascade amplifier
items.content:
Iteration 1: 1 error
Iteration 2: 3 errors (1 × 3)
Iteration 3: 9 errors (3 × 3)
Iteration 5: 81 errors

Cost at iteration 1: 1 unit. Cost at iteration 5: 121 units total.

items.title: Parallel speed vs. coordination overhead
items.content:
Independent agents: Fast parallel work, but 17.2x error amplification
Centralized coordination: Slower, but only 4.4x error amplification
Heuristic: As codebase grows, favor coordination over independence

items.title: Merge wall emergence at scale
items.content:
At small scale: parallel agents work beautifully.
At ~150k LOC: occasional conflicts, manageable.
At ~200k LOC: "merge wall" - conflicts constant.

"Works at 50k LOC" doesn't mean "works at 200k LOC"

items.title: Debug vs. Restart = Repair vs. Rebuild
items.content:
Repair (debug): Fix what's broken, keep the rest
Rebuild (restart): Start fresh with clean foundation
Hardware rule: If repair cost > 50% of replace, replace
Agent rule: If debug time > restart + redo time, restart

items.title: If OHIV isn't working
items.content:
Context collapsed? → Skip to restart, don't debug
Multi-agent chaos? → Kill all, use worktrees, restart isolated
Same error 3+ times? → Task too complex, split it
Costs spiking? → pkill first, debug later

items.title: If you push through with degraded context
items.content:
IF: Context at 90% but "almost done"
THEN: Quality degradation unnoticed
THEN: Errors introduced in "final" changes
THEN: "Done" code actually broken
FINALLY: More work than starting fresh would have been

The fix: Restart at 85%+. "Almost done" is a trap.

items.title: Debug vs. restart judgment
items.content:
Beginner: "Should I debug or restart?" → Use 10-min rule
Intermediate: "What signals indicate which?" → Context %, error count
Advanced: "Can I prevent needing either?" → Pre-session checklist
Staff: "When is debugging worth the investment?" → When it prevents future issues
Expert: "How do I make this decision automatic?" → Circuit breakers
